rev.diff:
Line 28: Line 28:
Mubarak dissolved his government and appointed military figure and former head of the [[Egyptian General Intelligence Directorate]] [[Omar Suleiman]] as Vice-President in an attempt to quell dissent. Mubarak asked aviation minister and former chief of Egypt's Air Force, [[Ahmed Shafik]], to form a new government. Opposition to the Mubarak regime has coalesced around [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], with all major opposition groups supporting his role as a negotiator for some form of transitional unity government.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Shadid|first=Anthony and David D. Kirpatrick|title=Opposition Rallies to ElBaradei as Military Reinforces in Cairo|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/31/world/middleeast/31-egypt.html|accessdate=31 January 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=30 January 2011}}</ref> In response to mounting pressure Mubarak announced he would not seek re-election in September,<ref>{{Cite news|author=El Deeb, Sarah; Al-Shalchi, Hadeel|title=Egypt Crowds Unmoved by Mubarak's Vow Not To Run|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory?id=12815050|accessdate=1 February 2011|publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[ABC News]]'')|date=1 February 2011}}</ref> and is reported to be considering resigning.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/20112101653445426.html |title=Hosni Mubarak 'may step down' |work=Al Jazeera English |date=10 February 2011 |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref>
Mubarak dissolved his government and appointed military figure and former head of the [[Egyptian General Intelligence Directorate]] [[Omar Suleiman]] as Vice-President in an attempt to quell dissent. Mubarak asked aviation minister and former chief of Egypt's Air Force, [[Ahmed Shafik]], to form a new government. Opposition to the Mubarak regime has coalesced around [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], with all major opposition groups supporting his role as a negotiator for some form of transitional unity government.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Shadid|first=Anthony and David D. Kirpatrick|title=Opposition Rallies to ElBaradei as Military Reinforces in Cairo|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/31/world/middleeast/31-egypt.html|accessdate=31 January 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=30 January 2011}}</ref> In response to mounting pressure Mubarak announced he would not seek re-election in September,<ref>{{Cite news|author=El Deeb, Sarah; Al-Shalchi, Hadeel|title=Egypt Crowds Unmoved by Mubarak's Vow Not To Run|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory?id=12815050|accessdate=1 February 2011|publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[ABC News]]'')|date=1 February 2011}}</ref> and is reported to be considering resigning.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/20112101653445426.html |title=Hosni Mubarak 'may step down' |work=Al Jazeera English |date=10 February 2011 |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref>
â
== Background==
+
== Background ==
Since the 1981 assassination of President [[Anwar El Sadat]], [[Hosni Mubarak]] has headed Egypt's [[Semi-presidential system|semi-presidential]] republic government and is the longest serving President in Egypt's history. Mubarak and his [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party (NDP)]] government have maintained one-party rule under a continuous state of emergency.<ref name="Hosni Mubarak">{{cite web|author=|url=http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/m/hosni_mubarak/index.html|title=Hosni Mubarak|work=The New York Times |date=8 March 2010|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Mubarak's government earned the support of the West and a continuation of annual aid from the United States by maintaining policies of suppression towards [[Islamic militants]] and peace with [[Israel]].<ref name="Hosni Mubarak" /> [[Hosni Mubarak]] has often been compared to an Egyptian [[pharaoh]] by the media and by some of his harsher critics due to his authoritarian rule.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/History-s-crossroads/748326 |title=Historyâs crossroads |publisher=Indianexpress.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref>
Since the 1981 assassination of President [[Anwar El Sadat]], [[Hosni Mubarak]] has headed Egypt's [[Semi-presidential system|semi-presidential]] republic government and is the longest serving President in Egypt's history. Mubarak and his [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party (NDP)]] government have maintained one-party rule under a continuous state of emergency.<ref name="Hosni Mubarak">{{cite web|author=|url=http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/m/hosni_mubarak/index.html|title=Hosni Mubarak|work=The New York Times |date=8 March 2010|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Mubarak's government earned the support of the West and a continuation of annual aid from the United States by maintaining policies of suppression towards [[Islamic militants]] and peace with [[Israel]].<ref name="Hosni Mubarak" /> [[Hosni Mubarak]] has often been compared to an Egyptian [[pharaoh]] by the media and by some of his harsher critics due to his authoritarian rule.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/History-s-crossroads/748326 |title=Historyâs crossroads |publisher=Indianexpress.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref>
Line 41: Line 41:
The deployment of plainclothes forces paid by Mubarak's ruling party, ''Baltageya''<ref name="Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash"/> ({{lang-ar|Ø¨ÙØ·Ø¬ÙØ©}}), has been a hallmark of the Mubarak government.<ref name="Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash">{{registration required|date=February 2011}} {{Cite news|author= Kirkpatrick, David; Fahim, Kareem|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/middleeast/26egypt.html|title=Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash|work=[[The New York Times]] |date=3 February 2011| accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> The [[Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights]] has documented 567 cases of torture, including 167 deaths, by police that occurred between 1993 and 2007.<ref>{{Cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6943704.stm|title=Egyptian Police Sued for Boy's Death|work=[[BBC News]]|date=13 August 2007|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> On 6 June 2010, [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed|Khaled Mohamed Saeed died under disputed circumstances]] in the [[Sidi Gaber]] area of [[Alexandria]]. Multiple witnesses testified that Saeed was beaten to death by the police.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Khalil, Ashraf|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/anger-alexandria-we%E2%80%99re-afraid-our-own-government|title=Anger in Alexandria: 'We're Afraid of Our Own Government'|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=25 June 2010|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Two Witnesses Affirm Alexandria Victim Beaten by Police|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/two-witnesses-affirm-alex-victim-beaten-police|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=19 June 2010|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref> Activists rallying around a Facebook page called "We are all Khaled Said" succeeded in bringing nationwide attention to the case.<ref>{{cite web|last=Levinson |first=Charles |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703445904576118502819408990.html |title=Wall Street Journal |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], former head of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]], led a rally in 2010 in Alexandria against alleged abuses by the police and visited Saeed's family to offer condolences.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/06/201062642955204618.html|title=ElBaradei Leads Anti-Torture Rally|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=26 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref>
The deployment of plainclothes forces paid by Mubarak's ruling party, ''Baltageya''<ref name="Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash"/> ({{lang-ar|Ø¨ÙØ·Ø¬ÙØ©}}), has been a hallmark of the Mubarak government.<ref name="Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash">{{registration required|date=February 2011}} {{Cite news|author= Kirkpatrick, David; Fahim, Kareem|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/middleeast/26egypt.html|title=Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash|work=[[The New York Times]] |date=3 February 2011| accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> The [[Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights]] has documented 567 cases of torture, including 167 deaths, by police that occurred between 1993 and 2007.<ref>{{Cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6943704.stm|title=Egyptian Police Sued for Boy's Death|work=[[BBC News]]|date=13 August 2007|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> On 6 June 2010, [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed|Khaled Mohamed Saeed died under disputed circumstances]] in the [[Sidi Gaber]] area of [[Alexandria]]. Multiple witnesses testified that Saeed was beaten to death by the police.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Khalil, Ashraf|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/anger-alexandria-we%E2%80%99re-afraid-our-own-government|title=Anger in Alexandria: 'We're Afraid of Our Own Government'|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=25 June 2010|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Two Witnesses Affirm Alexandria Victim Beaten by Police|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/two-witnesses-affirm-alex-victim-beaten-police|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=19 June 2010|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref> Activists rallying around a Facebook page called "We are all Khaled Said" succeeded in bringing nationwide attention to the case.<ref>{{cite web|last=Levinson |first=Charles |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703445904576118502819408990.html |title=Wall Street Journal |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], former head of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]], led a rally in 2010 in Alexandria against alleged abuses by the police and visited Saeed's family to offer condolences.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/06/201062642955204618.html|title=ElBaradei Leads Anti-Torture Rally|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=26 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref>
â   â
===Corruption===
  â
{{main|Crime in Egypt}}
  â   â
[[Political corruption]] in Mubarak administration's [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]] has risen dramatically due to the increased power over the institutional system necessary to prolong the presidency.<ref name="Egypt after Mubarak">{{Cite book|last=Rutherford|first=Bruce|title=Egypt after Mubarak: Liberalism, Islam, and Democracy in the Arab World|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|year=2008|month=November|isbn= 0-6911-3665-3}}</ref> The rise to power of powerful business men in the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] in the government and the People's Assembly led to massive waves of anger during the years of Prime Ministers [[Ahmed Nazif]]'s government. An example of that is [[Ahmed Ezz]]'s [[Monopoly|monopolizing]] the steel industry in Egypt by holding more than 60 percent of the market share.<ref name="Emerging Egypt 2007">{{Cite book|last=|first=|title=The Report: Egypt 2007|publisher=[[Oxford Business Group]]|year=2007|month=January|isbn= 1-9023-3957-6}}</ref> Aladdin Elaasar, an Egyptian biographer and an American professor, estimates that the Mubarak family is worth from $50 to $70 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/aladdin-elaasar/egyptians-rise-against-th_b_815520.html |title=Egyptians Rise Against Their Pharoah |work=[[Huffington Post]] |last=Elaasar |first=Aladdin |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/egypt-mubarak-family-accumulated-wealth-days-military/story?id=12821073&page=2|title=Egypt's Mubarak Likely to Retain Vast Wealth|publisher=[[ABC NEWS]]|accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
The wealth of Ahmed Ezz, the former NDP Organisation Secretary, is estimated to be 18 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions">{{cite web|url=http://www.allheadlinenews.com/briefs/articles/90033584?Obama%20optimistic%20about%20Egypt%20as%20negotiators%20make%20concessions|title=Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions|publisher=AHN|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref> The wealth of former Housing Minister Ahmed al-Maghraby is estimated to be more than 11 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions"/> The wealth of former Minister of Tourism Zuhair Garrana is estimated to be 13 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions"/> The wealth of former Minister of Trade and Industry, Rashid Mohamed Rashid, is estimated to be 12 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions"/> and the wealth of former Interior Minister Habib al-Adly is estimated to be 8 billion Egyptian pounds.<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions"/>
  â   â
The perceptions of corruption and its beneficiaries being limited to businessmen with ties to the National Democratic Party have created a picture "where wealth fuels political power and political power buys wealth."<ref>{{cite web|author=Inside Story |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/programmes/insidestory/2011/02/201128111236245847.html |title=How did Egypt become so corrupt? - Inside Story |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref>
  â   â
In 2010, [[Transparency International]]'s [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] report assessed Egypt with a CPI score of 3.1, based on perceptions of the degree of corruption from business people and country analysts (with 10 being clean and 0 being totally corrupt).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2010/results|title=CPI 2010 table|publisher=[[Transparency International]]|accessdate=26 October 2010}}</ref>
 
=== Economic challenges ===
=== Economic challenges ===
Line 66: Line 55:
Egypt's economy was highly centralized during the rule of former President [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] but opened up considerably under former President Anwar Sadat and Mubarak. The city of Cairo{{Clarify|date=February 2011}}<!--not the whole country?--> from 2004 to 2008 aggressively pursued economic reforms to attract foreign investment and facilitate GDP growth, but postponed further economic reforms because of global economic turmoil. The international [[economic downturn]] slowed Egypt's GDP growth to 4.5 percent in 2009. In 2010, analysts assessed the government of Prime Minister [[Ahmed Nazif]] would need to restart economic reforms to attract foreign investment, boost growth, and improve economic conditions for the broader population. Despite high levels of national economic growth over the past few years, living conditions for the average Egyptian remained poor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theodora.com/wfbcurrent/egypt/egypt_economy.html|title=Egypt Economy 2010|source=[[CIA World Factbook]]|date=27 January 2010|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
Egypt's economy was highly centralized during the rule of former President [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] but opened up considerably under former President Anwar Sadat and Mubarak. The city of Cairo{{Clarify|date=February 2011}}<!--not the whole country?--> from 2004 to 2008 aggressively pursued economic reforms to attract foreign investment and facilitate GDP growth, but postponed further economic reforms because of global economic turmoil. The international [[economic downturn]] slowed Egypt's GDP growth to 4.5 percent in 2009. In 2010, analysts assessed the government of Prime Minister [[Ahmed Nazif]] would need to restart economic reforms to attract foreign investment, boost growth, and improve economic conditions for the broader population. Despite high levels of national economic growth over the past few years, living conditions for the average Egyptian remained poor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theodora.com/wfbcurrent/egypt/egypt_economy.html|title=Egypt Economy 2010|source=[[CIA World Factbook]]|date=27 January 2010|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
â
===Foreign relations===
+
===Corruption===
â
{{main|Foreign relations of Egypt}}
+
{{main|Crime in Egypt}}
â
Foreign governments in the West including the US have regarded Mubarak as an important ally and [[Foreign relations of Egypt#Israeli-Palestinian conflict|supporter]] in the [[Israeli-Palestinian conflict|Israeli-Palestinian]] peace negotiations.<ref name="Hosni Mubarak"/> After wars with [[Israel]] in 1967 and '73, Egypt signed a [[EgyptâIsrael Peace Treaty|peace treaty]] in 1979, provoking controversy in the [[Arab world]]. As provisioned in the 1978 [[Camp David Accords]], which led to the peace treaty, both Israel and Egypt receive billions of dollars in aid annually from the United States, with Egypt receiving over US$1.3 billion of military aid each year in addition to economic and development assistance.<ref>{{cite web| title = Background Note: Egypt| publisher=[[United States Department of State]]| date =10 November 2010| url = http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/5309.htm| accessdate = 28 January 2011}}</ref> Many Egyptian youth feel ignored by Mubarak on the grounds that he is not looking out for their best interests and that he rather serves the interests of the [[West]].{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=this is based on opinion essay (by juan cole). needs clear wording and proper disclosure that it is cole speaking and not wikipedia with OR.}}<ref name="cole">{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/01/30/opinion/main20030008.shtml|title=Why Egypt's Class Conflict Is Boiling Over â Juan Cole: How Decades of Economic Stumbles Set the Stage for Egypt's Current Political Turmoil|author=Cole, Juan ([[essay]])|date=30 January 2011|work=[[CBS News]]|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> The cooperation of the Egyptian regime in enforcing the [[blockade of the Gaza Strip]] was also deeply unpopular amongst the general Egyptian public.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/jan/25/egypt.israelandthepalestinians1 |title=Mubarak under pressure | World news | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref>
+
[[Political corruption]] in Mubarak administration's [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]] has risen dramatically due to the increased power over the institutional system necessary to prolong the presidency.<ref name="Egypt after Mubarak">{{Cite book|last=Rutherford|first=Bruce|title=Egypt after Mubarak: Liberalism, Islam, and Democracy in the Arab World|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|year=2008|month=November|isbn= 0-6911-3665-3}}</ref> The rise to power of powerful business men in the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] in the government and the People's Assembly led to massive waves of anger during the years of Prime Ministers [[Ahmed Nazif]]'s government. An example of that is [[Ahmed Ezz]]'s [[Monopoly|monopolizing]] the steel industry in Egypt by holding more than 60 percent of the market share.<ref name="Emerging Egypt 2007">{{Cite book|last=|first=|title=The Report: Egypt 2007|publisher=[[Oxford Business Group]]|year=2007|month=January|isbn= 1-9023-3957-6}}</ref> Aladdin Elaasar, an Egyptian biographer and an American professor, estimates that the Mubarak family is worth from $50 to $70 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/aladdin-elaasar/egyptians-rise-against-th_b_815520.html |title=Egyptians Rise Against Their Pharoah |work=[[Huffington Post]] |last=Elaasar |first=Aladdin |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/egypt-mubarak-family-accumulated-wealth-days-military/story?id=12821073&page=2|title=Egypt's Mubarak Likely to Retain Vast Wealth|publisher=[[ABC NEWS]]|accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref>
â
===Military===
+
The wealth of Ahmed Ezz, the former NDP Organisation Secretary, is estimated to be 18 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions">{{cite web|url=http://www.allheadlinenews.com/briefs/articles/90033584?Obama%20optimistic%20about%20Egypt%20as%20negotiators%20make%20concessions|title=Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions|publisher=AHN|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref> The wealth of former Housing Minister Ahmed al-Maghraby is estimated to be more than 11 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions"/> The wealth of former Minister of Tourism Zuhair Garrana is estimated to be 13 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions"/> The wealth of former Minister of Trade and Industry, Rashid Mohamed Rashid, is estimated to be 12 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions"/> and the wealth of former Interior Minister Habib al-Adly is estimated to be 8 billion Egyptian pounds.<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions"/>
â
{{main|Military of Egypt}}
  â
The [[Egyptian Armed Forces]] enjoy a better reputation with the public than police, the former perceived as a professional body protecting the country, the latter accused of systemic corruption and illegitimate violence. All four Egyptian presidents since the 1950s have come from the military into power. Key Egyptian military personnel include the defense minister [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]] and General [[Sami Hafez Enan]], chief of staff of the armed forces.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Ian Black (journalist)|Black, Ian]]|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/30/egypt-military-hosni-mubarak|title=All Eyes on Egypt's Military as Hosni Mubarak Fortifies Position |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> The Egyptian military totals around 468,500 well-armed active personnel, plus a reserve of 479,000.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/30/uk-egypt-protests-military-idUKTRE70T29420110130|title=Factbox â Egypt's Powerful Military|work=[[Reuters]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
+
The perceptions of corruption and its beneficiaries being limited to businessmen with ties to the National Democratic Party have created a picture "where wealth fuels political power and political power buys wealth."<ref>{{cite web|author=Inside Story |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/programmes/insidestory/2011/02/201128111236245847.html |title=How did Egypt become so corrupt? - Inside Story |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref>
â
===Alexandria church bombing===
+
During the [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010]], opposition groups complained of harrassment and fraud perpetrated by the government. As such opposition and civil society activists have called for changes to [[National Association for Change#Platform|a number of legal]] and [[National Association for Change#Goals|constitutional provisions which affect elections]].
â
{{main|2011 Alexandria bombing}}
  â
Early on New Year's Day 2011 a bomb exploded in front of a church in Alexandria, killing 23 [[Copts|Coptic]] Christians. Egyptian officials said "foreign elements" were behind the attack.<ref>{{Cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Egypt Church Blast Death Toll Rises to 23|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE7010M020110104|work=[[Reuters]]|date=4 January 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> Some Copts accused the Egyptian government of negligence,<ref name="Clashes Grow">{{registration required|date=February 2011}} {{Cite news| last= Slackman| first= Michael| url= http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/04/world/middleeast/04egypt.html| title= Clashes Grow as Egyptians Remain Angry After an Attack|work=[[The New York Times]] | date= 4 January 2011| accessdate= }}</ref> and following the attacks many Christians protested in the streets, with Muslims later joining the protests. After clashing with the police, protesters in Alexandria and Cairo shouted slogans denouncing Mubarak's rule<ref>{{Cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Egypt Media Warn of Civil War after Bombing|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gM4ojQSkgen45AIWUkmRXYIsEFwA|accessdate=28 January 2011|publisher =''[[Agence France-Presse]]'' (via ''[[Google News]]'')|date=2 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{registration required|date=February 2011}} {{Cite news|author=Stack, Liam; Kirkpatrick, David D.|title=Egypt Orders Tighter Security After Church Bombing|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/03/world/middleeast/03egypt.html?partner=rss&emc=rss|accessdate=28 January 2011|work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Jouini|first=Hassen|title=Muslims Protect Churches|url=http://www.nationalpost.com/news/world/Muslims+protect+churches/4078614/story.html|accessdate=28 January 2011|work=[[National Post]]|date=8 January 2011}}</ref> in support of unity of Christians and Muslims. Their sense of being let down by national security forces has been cited as one of the first signs of the 25 January uprising.<ref>Interview. "Vivian Ibrahim of the [[School of Oriental and African Studies]] at the [[University of London]]". ''[[BBC News]]'' 3 February 2011; 12:55 UTC.</ref>
+
In 2010, [[Transparency International]]'s [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] report assessed Egypt with a CPI score of 3.1, based on perceptions of the degree of corruption from business people and country analysts (with 10 being clean and 0 being totally corrupt).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2010/results|title=CPI 2010 table|publisher=[[Transparency International]]|accessdate=26 October 2010}}</ref>
â   â
On February 7, a complaint was filed against Habib al-Adly, the Interior Minister until Mubarak's dissolution of the government during the early days of the protests, accusing him of having directed the attack.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/tuesday%E2%80%99s-papers-funeral-martyr-journalist-ghoneim-release-al-adli-under-investigation|title=Tuesdayâs papers: Funeral for martyr journalist, Ghoneim release, al-Adli under investigation|author=Heba Helmy|date=February 8, 2011|publisher-Al Masry Al Youm}}</ref>
  â   â
===2010 election===
  â
During the [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010]], opposition groups complained of harrassment and fraud perpetrated by the government. As such opposition and civil society activists have called for changes to [[National Association for Change#Platform|a number of legal]] and [[National Association for Change#Goals|constitutional provisions which affect elections]].
 
==Protests==
==Protests==
